entry.title: Analysis 3/4: Degree Distribution
entry.content:
Date: Fri Dec 26 22:26:54 2014
Analysis version (challprop-analytics): 7e2901a
(use git checkout $commit$ if needed)

Back to the experiment page

The number of out degrees of each agent is the same as in degrees, because we create reciprocal link for every link that is being created between two agents. Therefore we account only for outDegrees. The chart below shows that most of the agents have 0 to 3 outDegrees, but there are a few agents that have up to 13 connections to other agents.

## Total number of outDegrees:  19877

Back to the experiment page

entry.title: Analysis 3/2: Distribution of Challenges
entry.content:
Date: Sat Dec 27 01:00:17 2014
Analysis version (challprop-analytics): c275278
(use git checkout $commit$ if needed)

Back to the experiment page

Processes per agent

When an agent is challenged with the situation by generator of diversity, the agent may carry on few processes with it, which together form a ‘pipeline’ of processing that challenge. These ‘pipelines’ may differ from each other and are not predictable because the way the agent treats the challenge depends on, e.g. the intensity of it; there is also stochastic component. The usual pipeline of the challenge looks like this:

==>e[1bgbR-8NGA-1w][2097620-challenged->8331964]:
an agent No. 8331964 is challenged by G.O.D by a situation
==>e[1INbz-yXww-1M][8331964-interpreted->2097620]: 
the challenge is interpreted, intensity+ penalty calculated, etc.
==>e[1IN8p-yXww-1o][8331964-buffered->2097620]: 
the challenge is put into queue of an agent;
==>e[1INgV-yXww-22][8331964-processed->2097620]: 
it is processed (extraction of benefit, etc.);
==>e[1INef-yXww-1U][8331964-reinterpreted->2097620]: 
turned back to the situation and prepared for propagation;
==>e[1bgbP-8NGA-1w][2097620-challenged->5122808]: 
propagated further..
==>e[1cPSX-ad28-1E][2433384-forgot->2099552]: 
'sent to sink' so to speak, i.e. the situation drops out of propatation.

We can calculate how many these ‘elementary events’ happened on average for each agent during the simulation time (for the total number of the elementary events, see Analysis 3/1):

average number of elementary events per agent
eventsPerAgent
originalChallenges 20.00
challenged 74.15
interpreted 73.84
buffered 70.51
processed 58.95
penalized 73.84
benefitted 58.95
forgot 13.11
reinterpreted 58.95

Distribution of original challenges

The simulation goes this way: there are 10 thousand agents, 100 iterations. Each iteration 20% of agents get a fresh challenge generated by G-O-D, which is 2000 per iteration. These challenges in the beginning are (should be) distributed randomly across all agents in the network. If challenges are not distributed evenly across the network, that may cause buffers of agents lock some challenges and that would explain why we see somewhat low number of secondary propagation of challenges during further simulation. Lets see:

## The number of original challenges in the simulation:  200000

Distribution of all challenges

This should be different as after propagation the nice random pattern dissapears into what looks a kind of power-law distribution: some agents get much more challegnes than others (depends probably on the degree):

## Total number of all challenges in the simulation:  741477

A little discussion

Looks good in my opinion. One thing to notice is that each original challenge is further propagated on average 2.7 times. Not sure what does that mean though…

Back to the experiment page

entry.title: Analysis 3/1: Basic Statistics and Benefit Increase
entry.content:
Date: Fri Dec 26 20:53:55 2014
Analysis version (challprop-analytics): 57a1dde
Experiment version (challprop-experiments: b0c9813)
(use git checkout $commit$ if needed)

Back to the experiment page

Basic Statistics:

These very roughly characterize what kind of data structure we get out of simulation.

## 
## NUMBER OF VERTIXES:
## penaltyHolder=738410
## situationInst=789548
## benefitHolder=589548
## situation=200000
## agent=10000
## god=1
## 
## NUMBER OF EDGES:
## knowsLinks=19877
## challenged=741477
## interpreted=738410
## buffered=705070
## processed=589548
## reinterpreted=589548
## forgot=131106
## 
## PERFORMANCE:
## Number of atomic events: 3495159
## Total simulation time (secs): 35785.2884818130
## Total simulation time (hours): 9.9403579116
## Average time per atomic event (secs): 0.0102385295

Average benefit:

## 
## AVERAGE TOTAL BENEFIT:
## 97.19724245739971

Average benefit change per unit of time:

Discussion

The graph with average benefit change does not seem very interesting - the benefit just increases and looks quite different from the one produced by Evo in chalprop-matlab simulation with the same parameters (see presentation, page 9).

The second graph clearly shows that self-organization is not hapenning - the speed of benefit increase is constant during the whole simulation time. If zoomed the graph closely, you can see lines for fitted lines for average benefit, benefit and penalty all pretty close to zero…

Also, the average degree and number of knowsLinks in the graph is somewhat suspicious: 2 is way too little for what you would expect from 200,000 situations and 100 iterations. There are two possibilities as always - some sort of bug preventing the simulation run correctly or… feature of the algorithm.

I suppose the last is not a bug but a result of random jump parameter, which is 99 in case of this simulation (see analysis)

Back to the experiment page

entry.title: Analysis 2/4: Degree Distribution
entry.content:
Date: Tue Dec 23 13:08:44 2014
Analysis version (challprop-analytics): 826443e
(use git checkout $commit$ if needed) Back to the experiment page

By definition, the number of out degrees of each agent is the same as in degrees, because we create reciprocal link for every link that is being created between two agents. Therefore we account only for outDegrees. The chart below shows that most of the agents have 0 to 2 outDegrees, but there are a few agents that have up to 10 connections to other agents.

## Total number of outDegrees:  15524

What would be interesting to see now is:

  • whether degrees and and benefit corelate in any fashion (and maybe cummulated link weights / social capital);
  • is there a difference in benefit dynamics of agents with higher degree than lower degree (if the number of such agents is enough to make any inferences…)

Back to the experiment page

entry.title: Analysis 2/3: Distribution of Link Weights
entry.content:
Date: Sun Dec 21 18:59:04 2014
Analysis version (challprop-analytics): 5eb6e85
(use git checkout $commit$ if needed)

Back to the experiment page

First, the number of links in the graph: 25524. The graph is quite sparse given that we have 10k of agents. Further, 98% of all link weights are between -2 and 24:

##         1%        10%        20%        30%        40%        50% 
## -1.9254925  0.1371433  0.3666670  0.5908780  0.8212776  1.0899550 
##        60%        70%        80%        90%        99% 
##  1.4120276  1.8456976  2.5533804  4.1885262 23.9509453

Link weights are clearly biased towards positive: only 0.0437236 of all links have negative or zero weight.

Next, a simple density plot of 98% link weights (i.e. between -2 and 24):

This shows that most of the links are very small - very close to zero.

It would be nice to check out how degree distributions look like now..

Back to the experiment page
